MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Drugs Expenditure.

Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself with the present controls on the growth of expenditure on prescribed drugs; and if he will outline the scale of the reduction of expenditure on drugs in 1919 in comparison to 1990 as a result of the measures he has initiated.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The Government's strategy to control expenditure on prescribed drugs is a coordinated strategy which incorporates measures to control the price of drugs and measures, in co-operation with the medical profession, to ensure cost-effective and appropriate prescribing.

With regard to price, the Deputy will be aware of the present agreement between the Government and the Federation of Irish Chemical Industries which has resulted in a reduction of 10 per cent on average in the prices of drugs since the previous year. The main features of the new agreement is the breaking of the specific link between Irish prices and UK prices. In future price movements in Ireland will be linked to price movements in certain EC countries, rather than those in the United Kingdom alone, with a protection clause which prohibits the cost of any medicine in Ireland being higher than the UK price.

In relation to the area of cost effective prescribing the Deputy will be aware that the recent review of the GMS reached agreement on the action necessary. Their recommendations are being introduced on a phased basis. A national drugs formulary and a repeat prescription facility in the GMS scheme have been introduced already.

MainHeading.P: While detailed figures for 1991 drugs expenditure on the GMS scheme are not yet available, preliminary figures suggest that the rate of growth has fallen from that recorded in early 1990.

Qst.Quest: the reason the proportion of AIDS cases here show a far higher proportion of intravenous drug users than in the United Kingdom; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The pattern of spread of the virus in this country to date which is largely intravenous drug abuse related is similar to that in France, Italy and Spain. By contrast, the main source of spread in the United Kingdom, Germany and Scandanavia is homosexual. However, there is now evidence that in these countries intravenous drug misuse is gaining ground as a source of infection.

In recognition of the trend in this country our AIDS strategy has focused, inter alia, on actions aimed at reducing the incidence of needle sharing, both in terms of health education programmes and in Outreach contact. In addition a needle exchange programme has been successfully operated in the Dublin area where the main intravenous drug misuse problem exists. The results of a recent study in Ireland are encouraging in terms of the success of our strategy in that there is evidence of a decline in needle sharing from 67 per cent of persons surveyed who admitted to having shared needles at some time to 16 per cent who were so doing on treatment contract.
I have arranged to have a copy of the recently published “Government Strategy to Prevent Drug Misuse”, which deals with the link between drug misuse and AIDS, made available to the Deputy.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, his Department have to provide a new hospital and/or an additional medical facility at Lismore, County Waterford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The South-Eastern Health Board are responsible for the provision of health services in County Waterford. I understand that a local voluntary organisation have plans at an advanced stage to provide sheltered accommodation for the elderly on the site of the former district hospital at Lismore. In addition, the South-Eastern Health Board hope to develop a health centre and a day care centre for the elderly on the same site.
These proposals will be included in the plans being prepared by the board to implement the commitment to develop community health services contained in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I am satisfied that there is a high standard of food hygiene operated in the majority of mobile ice cream vending units. Where breaches of the Food Hygiene Regulations (1950-89) do occur prosecutions are taken by the health boards. Qst.Quest: the current number of beds in St. Camillus Geriatric Hospital, County Limerick; if he will outline his future plans for this hospital as there is serious concern that the number of beds will be reduced; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The management of St. Camillus Hospital is the responsibility of the Mid-Western Health Board. I have been informed by the board that there are 305 beds in the hospital at present.

In October 1990 the Mid-Western Health Board produced a plan of action to develop services for the elderly based on the recommendations of the report of the Working Party on Services for the Elderly — The Years Ahead — A Policy for the Elderly. It is the aim of the board to support the elderly and their carers at home for as long as possible and to provide extended care, when necessary, as close as possible to where the elderly person is living.

The board envisage that St. Camillus Hospital will provide a communityrelated service for a defined population in Limerick city and county. The emphasis will be on the provision of the following services: to increase the number of short stay rehabilitation beds from the current level of 12 beds to 36 beds; to increase the number of day hospital places from the current level of 20 places to 25 places; to provide an acute intervention service; to provide an enhanced unit for persons suffering from Alzheimers disease; to provide places for respite care, terminal care and continuing care.
The services provided at St. Camillus Hospital will continue to link in with the acute geriatric assessment unit in the regional hospital, Dooradoyle.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the findings which show that Ireland has (1) double the number of claims against doctors as the United Kingdom and (2) double the level of individual awards; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I am aware of the newspaper report which the Deputy refers to in his question. The source of the claim that Ireland has double the number of claims against doctors and double the level of individual awards as the United Kingdom would appear to be the Medical Defence Union, one of the two medical defence organisations which operate here. As the vast majority of claims for personal injury against doctors and hospitals are settled out of court by the relevant insurers there is very little published information on either the number of claims, the nature of these claims or the settlements arrived at.

The difference in the claims experience in Ireland should be looked at in the context of other areas of personal injury litigations, such as road traffic accidents, where there is also a higher level of claims and a higher level of settlements than the United Kingdom.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Health Care Services.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the general decline in the health care services in the country in general, particularly in the Cavan-Monaghan area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I do not accept that there has been such a decline. On the contrary, the Government's commitment to the health services is firmly underlined by the 1991 provision for the health services. The gross non-capital provision for the health services in 1991 amounts to over £1.5 billion.

The health service share of resources has increased each year since I came into office. This year, over one-fifth of total Government expenditure on non-capital supply services is devoted to the health services. In addition, the Government have made available an Exchequer capital provision of £32.330 million. A further £9 million will be made available from non-Exchequer sources, bringing the total capital provision to over £41 million.

The Government's commitment to health care is shown clearly in the provision of better facilities. New or extended hospitals have been provided at Beaumont, the Mater and St. James's in Dublin and at Cavan, Mullingar, Sligo, Waterford and Wexford.

A full accident and emergency service is now provided at six Dublin hospitals. Reducing waiting lists has also been successfully tackled. Last year the waiting lists for hip replacements were reduced by 16 per cent, the waiting lists for cataracts were reduced by 12 per cent and the waiting lists for ENT (including tonsils and adenoids) were reduced by 9 per cent in 1990 and 12 per cent since July 1990.

Particular emphasis has been given to community-based services for the elderly, the mentally-handicapped, the physically disabled and for children at risk. In the last two years, £8 million extra was allocated to services for the elderly, £3 million extra was allocated to services for people with mental handicap. The number of places at day centres and day hospitals has almost trebled since 1984 and places at hostels and in community residence have doubled. Six million pounds extra has been provided to develop dental services and it is now proposed to appoint an orthodontist in each health board area.

MainHeading.P: Furthermore, arising from the Programme for Economic and Social Progress, a seven year investment programme will provide £100 million capital funds to develop community-based services and an increase of £90 million in day-to-day spending on these services.

These are just some indications of the areas in which the Government have invested heavily and will continue to do so in the future. Rather than there being a decline in health care services, their development has been put on a very sound footing.
Likewise, the suggestion that there is a decline in the health care services, particularly in the Cavan-Monaghan area, is not borne out by the facts.

In Counties Cavan and Monaghan hospital services have improved substantially since the new Cavan General Hospital opened in June 1989. Four additional consultants were appointed. Admissions increased by 27 per cent from 1989 to 1990 and out-patient numbers increased by 38 per cent. A new paediatric department also opened in April 1990 with two consultant paediatricians serving Counties Cavan and Monaghan. Building has recently commenced of a new out-patient extension at Monaghan General Hospital which will include consulting rooms, enhanced casualty facilities, new lift shaft and upgrading of the existing physiotherapy department and toilet accommodation.

Services for the elderly continue to be improved through the provision of additional staffing and facilities. Psychiatric services also continue to be developed. A 25 bed acute psychiatric unit has been opened in the new Cavan General Hospital. Community psychiatric services in the two counties are well developed with the provision of additional day hospital, day centre and hostel places. Services for those with mental handicap continue to be improved. Additional funding has also been provided to enhance the dental services in the area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Department of Nursing Studies.

Qst.hpid: Mr. T. O'Sullivan Mr. T. O'Sullivan
Qst.Quest: if he is prepared, in conjunction with UCC, to set up a department of nursing studies at the Faculty of Medicine, at University College, Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The need for such a department would have to be justified by reference to some inadequacy in the present arrangements for nurse training. There is fairly general agreement on the excellent quality of Irish nursing, and this is evidenced by the ready access offered to Irish nurses to employment abroad.

While there is a trend internationally towards the placement of nurse training in a more academic setting, there would need to be a convincing case to justify such a change in the Irish context, given the degree of satisfaction with the existing training system. The various options for nurse training are currently the subject of review by An Bord Altranais. In any event, the establishment of any new department within a university is a matter for the individual college and the Minister for Education.

I should point out that these figures include both public and non-public patients treated in public hospitals. Up to now, hospitals did not distinguish between public and non-public patients in maintaining waiting lists for ENT services and therefore it is not possible to give a breakdown as between the two categories. With the revised eligibility arrangements, hospitals will, in future, be required to maintain separate waiting lists for public and private patients.

Waiting times vary considerably from centre to centre and depending on the priority accorded to an individual case. For these reasons, it is not possible to give a national average waiting time from ENT procedures.

Waiting lists are a feature of health care systems throughout the world as the demands for health care will always exceed the capacity of the available resources to meet it. I am, however, acutely aware of the problems which arose in relation to waiting lists for ear, nose and throat services and I took steps to deal with this situation. Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: whether his attention has been drawn to the difficulties for the blind in relation to access to premises where dogs are not allowed; if he will ensure as far as possible both by way of regulation and exhortation that guide dogs are exempted from any such prohibitions; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The consistent policy of my Department over a long number of years has been that with the exception of guide dogs, no animals are permissible in catering premises. This has been communicated clearly to the health boards for over the past 15 years and they in turn have informed the owners of cafes, hotels, shops, supermarkets and other catering establishments. My Department are in frequent contact with the Irish Guide Dogs Association in an effort to ensure that the blind who must use guide dogs are not discommoded or embarrassed.
In the case of national hygiene campaigns, the special position of the blind who depend on guide dogs has always been brought to the attention of those involved in the catering trade.

The environmental health officers of the health boards who are responsible for the enforcement of the food hygiene regulations have always recognised the special position of the guide dogs for the blind and brought this to the attention of the owners of food premises.

A further circular issued from my Department to the chief executive officers of the health boards last week reiterating the need to exempt bona fide guide dogs for the use of the blind from the food hygiene regulations.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: if he is in a position to take any steps to prevent the dumping on the Irish market of products by a Swedish company (details supplied) in order to protect Irish firms in the same business from unfair foreign competition; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: The EC Commission is responsible for investigating complaints of dumping by third countries in the Community market and for proposing protective action. Such investigations are initiated only on receipt of a dumping complaint, which is the responsibility of the affected industry.

One Irish company has recently indicated that it is being subjected to unfair competition from alleged dumping by the Swedish company named by the Deputy. Accordingly, my Department have issued it with a guide to the EC Anti-Dumping Regulation, together with a questionnaire produced by the EC Commission which is designed to facilitate the preparation of complaints against dumped imports. Additionally, the company have been invited to contact the expert official in my Department so that whatever advice they require will be provided.

Finally, I would like to assure the Deputy that, in all cases where Irish industry demonstrates, in the required way, that it is adversely affected by dumped imports, my Department vigorously pursue the matter at EC level, in an effort to secure adequate remedies. In this case, too, every assistance will be given to the industry, should it decide to lodge a formal complaint.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the demand in many housing estates in County Dublin for connection to the natural gas grid; if he has satisfied himself that Bord Gáis Éireann are doing enough to satisfy that demand; if he would urge Bord Gáis Éireann to state clearly their connection policy and to accelerate their programme so that all estates can have access to this clean form of energy; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. Molloy) Robert Molloy
Speaker.P: I am aware of the growing demand for gas in areas not currently served by the grid and, as I have told the House in reply to previous questions, Bord Gáis Éireann are developing a programme to extend the grid to non-gas estates in the Dublin area and in other centres.

MainHeading.P: This programme will, of course, be very costly and will take a number of years to complete. Extension to individual non-gas estates will naturally depend on the level of uptake in each case. Bord Gáis Éireann have a statutory responsibility to earn a reasonable return on their capital investment and must, therefore, assess all extensions on a commercial basis. Only those estates which are identified as viable will be connected.

The board have recently undertaken a pilot project in two Dublin estates which have shown positive, but marginal, results and on the basis of this pilot project, and subject to take-up, the board are proposing to extend supply to an additional 8,000 homes in hitherto non-gas estates throughout the country in 1991. Some 32 estates in the Dublin area, involving about 6,000 houses, will be approached.
It would be my intention that all viable estates in the gas supply area would be connected within five years.

Qst.Quest: the reason a disabled person (details supplied) in Dublin 3 was refused a companion bus pass since she is unable to travel alone; and if he will review the decision.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The person concerned currently holds a free travel pass having retained her entitlement on transferring from invalidity pension to retirement pension at age 65.

Last year, I extended the free travel scheme to enable a companion to travel free of charge with a recipient of disabled person's maintenance allowance (DPMA) who was unable to travel alone. This year, I am going one step further by allowing DPMA recipients to retain their entitlement to free travel when they enter residential care and, thereby, avail of the “companion” pass.

As the person concerned is not in receipt of disabled person's maintenance allowance, it is not possible to grant a “companion” pass in her case. The question of further extending the “companion” pass is a matter for consideration in a budgetary context.

Qst.Quest: when a lone parent allowance will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Wexford whose application was received in his Department on 11 March 1991.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: Aspects of the claim by the person concerned for a lone parent allowance require further investigation by the social welfare officer. This will be finalised shortly and a decision will then be given on the claim.

Qst.Quest: the reason a person (details supplied) in Carlow has been assessed as having an income of £106.04 when he is actually out of work.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The person concerned claimed unemployment assistance on 11 February 1991. He was assessed with means of £106.10 derived from self-employment as a carpenter and from a small amount of capital. The deciding officer took the view that he could reasonably expect to enjoy the same opportunities for self-employment as he has experienced in the preceding year and assessed his earnings accordingly. This assessment left him entitled to a weekly payment of £2.90.
The means assessed against him were confirmed on appeal. He has not signed the unemployed register since 25 March 1991.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Motor Insurance Offences Statistics.

Qst.Quest: if he will consider requesting the gardaí to keep relevant statistics for motor insurance offences detected by the Force in view of the difficulties people under 25 years of age experience in trying to obtain insurance cover; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that as things stand it is not possible for the Force to compile accurate statistics in respect of prosecutions or convictions for motor insurance related offences by reference to the ages of the persons in question. The possibility of doing so when all driving licences on issue are of the new style which includes the holder's date of birth is something which can be considered. Whether the availability of more detailed statistics of this kind would cause insurance companies to reduce the cost of cover for persons under 25 years of age is another matter.

Qst.Quest: when he intends to introduce legislation to ensure the maintenance, upkeep and repair of courthouses will be transferred from being the responsibility of the local authority to that of another body; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: The Deputy will appreciate that, as I have stated in the House on previous occasions, I could not undertake to indicate in reply to a parliamentary question what legislative proposals I might have in any particular area. Any legislative proposals which I may have in relation to the maintenance, upkeep and repair of courthouses will be announced in the ordinary way in due course.

I might add, however, that, while local authorities continue to be responsible for courthouses, under new administrative arrangements being introduced this year my Department will recoup to them the full capital cost of approved major renovation schemes, together with some of the maintenance costs. All allocation of funds for this purpose has been included in the Courts Vote for 1991.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - District and Circuit Court Jurisdictions.

Qst.Quest: if he intends to introduce legislation to increase the civil jurisdiction of the District Court and Circuit Court; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: My proposals for increasing the jurisdictions of the District and Circuit Courts are contained in the Courts (No. 2) Bill, 1991, which was circulated to Deputies yesterday.

Qst.Quest: if he will establish a central registry where victims of moneylending could register full details of agreements with moneylenders and which would act as a source of information for people as to their rights under the appropriate moneylending legislation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: The existing legislation on moneylending is being reviewed in the context of Council Directive 87/102/EEC on consumer credit, implementation of which is a matter for my collegue the Minister for Industry and Commerce. The Minister has informed me that work in his Department is well advanced on the preparation of draft legislation to give effect to the Council Directive. The legislation will lay down rules to apply as far as possible to all forms of credit provided for consumers, including moneylending agreements. The legislation will provide for appropriate penalties for branches of its provisions.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Motor Cycle Pillion Passenger Insurance.

Qst.Quest: if he has taken any steps to introduce compulsory insurance cover for motorcycle pillion passengers, particularly in light of an EC directive for 1998; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: I will make regulations by the end of 1992 requiring the compulsory insurance of motor cycle pillion passengers with effect from 31 December 1998. This implementation time scale is in accordance with the requirements of Council Directive 90/232/EEC of 14 May 1990.

Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself with regulations governing the storage of LPG storage tanks in motor vehicles having particular regard to where such a vehicle is involved in a road traffic accident; if he will outline the checks which are carried out to ensure that the fitting of such tanks is correct; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: Standards for the installation of LPG fuel systems, including LPG storage tanks, in motor vehicles are contained in an Irish Standard Specification — IS 404 of 1987. The standard has been the subject of a series of amendments, the most recent in March 1991. This voluntary standard was adopted by the National Standards Authority of Ireland, at my Department's request and with the consent of the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

It is open to installers of LPG fuel systems to certify that the system in a specified motor vehicle has been installed, examined and tested in accordance with the requirements of IS 404 of 1987 and found to be satisfactory. Enforcement in relation to the validity of any such certification is primarily a matter for the Minister for Industry and Commerce.
I propose to consider making regulations under the Road Traffic Act to make IS 404 of 1987 a compulsory standard and consultations with interested parties on this will shortly be initiated.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Qst.Quest: when he proposes to make available to Dublin County Council the necessary funds for resurfacing roads in the vicinity of the Shankill-Bray by-pass.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: Dublin County Council's proposals for the Shankill-Bray by-pass, which were approved by my Department, made provision for improvements to some adjoining non-national roads where the work was deemed necessary as a direct consequence of the construction of the by-pass. These works are being financed from road grants allocated to the by-pass, including the grant of £9 million for the current year.

In the case of other non-national roads in the area, responsibility for the planning and execution of any improvement works on them, including the provision of the necessary finance, rests with Dublin County Council as the road authority for the area. The council may use the discretionary grants for regional and county roads, provided by my Department, to supplement expenditure from the authority's own resources on such works. Discretionary grants totalling £1,395 million have been allocated to Dublin County Council for 1991.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Assistant City and County Manager Posts.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the representations which he has received from trade unions and staff associations concerning the recent advertisement for three assistant city and county managers for Dublin county and (2) the discussions he has had or intends to have with the unions and associations concerned; and when he expects appointments will be made arising from the advertisements.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: Three Assistant County Manager (Area Manager) posts for County Dublin, created by section 21 of the Local Government Act, 1991, were advertised recently. Under that section, the statutory request to the Local Appointments Commissioners in respect of recommendations for appointment to these three posts was deemed to have been made upon the commencement of the section i.e. on 21 May 1991. While the arrangements for the holding of the competition for the filling of the posts are a matter for the commission, the provisions of Part IV of the Act relating to reorganisation of local government in County Dublin require that these appointments be made as soon as possible. I understand, however, that having regard to the various procedures involved, the persons to be appointed are likely to be in place before the autumn.

The arrangements for filling these posts were raised in the course of consultations and correspondence between my Department and trade unions and associations concerned. These consultations related mainly to the provisions of the Act governing the tenure of office of managers.

I received a separate request from Dublin County Council Senior Officers Association for a meeting to discuss the reorganisation arrangements in County Dublin. Consultation at local level was suggested and I understand that such consultation is taking place.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Domiciliary Care Allowance Eligibility.

Qst.Quest: if any financial aid is available to the parents of a moderately mentally handicapped child who does not qualify for a medical card.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The parents of a child with a mental handicap may, subject to a medical examination and means test by the child, qualify for a domiciliary care allowance of £83 per month if the child is under 16 years of age. Children over 16 may qualify for a disabled persons maintenance allowance of £52 per week in their own right. In addition, the parents of a child with a mental handicap may qualify for a tax free allowance of £600 per annum. Also, all persons with a mental handicap, regardless of age, can obtain drugs and medicines necessary for their condition, free of charge.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to (1) the lack of dental services in Killarney town schools and (2) the fact that the Southern Health Board's dental programme in Killarney area is grossly inadequate; if he will outline his proposals to rectify the problem; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I understand from the Southern Health Board that the board is finalising plans to provide additional dental units in Killarney to cater for the Killarney schools. The priority of the board, with regard to national school children, is to ensure that first, third and sixth classes receive attention each year. In the current year all children in sixth class in the Killarney schools will receive attention. With the provision of additional facilities it is expected that the targets will be met in the academic year 1991-92.

There are at present 37 adults on the waiting list for dental treatment in the Killarney area. These will be dealt with by the board's own dental services and under arrangements made by the board with private practitioners. As the Deputy will be aware a special allocation was again made available to health boards in 1991 to maintain improvements in adult dental services.

I might mention that a special allocation is being provided by my Department to enable the health board to commence additional orthodontic treatments in 1991. Also, a vacancy for a consultant orthodontist in the health board, with improved conditions and salary, was recently advertised by the Local Appointments Commission.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke

Qst.Quest: when her Department will sanction the appointment of an additional teacher to the staff of Carysfort national school, Blackrock, County Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware the staffing of a national school is determined by the enrolment in the school on the 30 September of the previous year. This is in accordance with the agreement made between the Government and the INTO. In the case of Carysfort national school, Blackrock, there were 297 pupils enrolled on the 30 September 1990, which warrants a staff of principal plus nine assistants for the 1991/92 school year. The school will also have the services of a full-time remedial teacher.

The only exceptions that can be made to the agreed staffing arrangements are in the case of developing schools or where my Department's guidelines on maximum class sizes are being breached. An application has been received by my Department for the appointment of an additional assistant to the school in September 1991, on the basis that it is a developing school. My Department are currently examining this application and will be in touch with the school authorities shortly.

Qst.Quest: if she will outline the progress which is being made regarding an extension to a primary school (details supplied) in County Kilkenny.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: My Department's architect has recently inspected the site extension to the national school in County Kilkenny referred to by the Deputy which is required for the school project. When the school authorities confirm that the land is available and its extent my Department will undertake a feasibility study for the scheme. I am aware of the Deputy's interest in this matter and will keep him informed of developments.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the terms of reference under which Eolas are carrying out an assessment of the effects of the new Dublin Airport runway on neighbouring properties and residents including the proposed offers from Aer Rianta and the requests of the residents; and when Eolas will be making their report having regard to the fact that the runway is not in use.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware, Eolas were requested at the end of April, 1991 to carry out as a matter of urgency an independent assessment of all aspects of the noise insulation arrangements provided by Aer Rianta for the householders affected by the coming into operation of the new runway. As I outlined in my reply to a parliamentary question on 20 March 1991, the Aer Rianta arrangements provide for comprehensive noise insulation levels, including provision for double glaxing and roof insulation.

The purpose of the Eolas investigation is to make an assessment of both the Aer Rianta arrangements for insulation of the house affected and the concerns of the St. Margaret's Community Council to maintain their quality of life.

I am not in a position to indicate at this point in time when the assessment by Eolas will be completed. I understand that meetings have already taken place between Eolas and the interested parties, including representatives of St. Margaret's Community Council.
